reading_mnemonic: The reading is an exception, but it isn't too hard to remember. It's the same as <reading>中</reading> (なか), so if you think about it it makes sense. It's your insides, just like your <vocabulary>belly</vocabulary> is your insides!
The readings are 一人 plus 娘 put together into one, single (daughter) word.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that 一 becomes いっ, and 杯 becomes ぱい.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for 杯, which becomes ばい thanks to our old friend rendaku.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 健康 first.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The <reading>川</reading> (かわ) has started <vocabulary>to get dry</vocabulary>. Need to use less water around here otherwise it'll become completely dry.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for the はい turning into ぱい!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This uses the same reading you learned with 任せる.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Someone with a weird accent is trying <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary> you to eat "Unagah" (うなが). This person really means "unagi," and this person also doesn't realize how delicious unagi is (and thinks he's tricking you). You ask him what "Unagah" is. Go ahead and say it out loud.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
For this reading, just imagine this as 入り with 江 pushed on at the end! Also note this is commonly written as 入江, but the reading stays the same!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just don't forget that extra い!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

To remember the reading think about how you are going <vocabulary>to recommend</vocabulary> this restaurant to your friends, <reading>Sue</reading> and <reading>Sue</reading> (すす). You refer to them as "Sue Sue" to make things easier on yourself, and they're always looking for recommendations.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The thing you broke? A beautiful ceramic <reading>koa</reading>la (こわ). Watch it shatter to the ground, because you threw it there. What a jerk you are.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

At a <vocabulary>banquet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>dinner party</vocabulary>, you don't only get food, you also <reading>歌 GE</reading>T (うたげ), which is you getting a song from a singer, because entertainment is just as important as the food when you have a <vocabulary>feast</vocabulary> such as this.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you're too shy to <vocabulary>draw near</vocabulary> to people, just learn how to use a <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ)! Then people will draw near to YOU to compliment you on your sick skills. You won't have to do it yourself!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
If you want <vocabulary>to get a position</vocabulary>, there are <reading>two</reading> (つ) interviews. Just pass the two interviews to get a job!
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 怒る, so you should know this one too!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

I have a lot of <vocabulary>anger</vocabulary> because <reading>I ca</reading>rry (いか) all of my own things (books, luggage, drinks) and no one will ever carry them for me. Plus, the more things I carry, the more anger I carry inside. Ahh!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You know what's really <vocabulary>scary</vocabulary>, like double scary (because kanji and vocab both mean scary)? How about your <reading>cowo</reading>rkers (こわ). They are all insane, and you know it. Absolute nutjobs they are.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

How <vocabulary>terrifying</vocabulary> is it? It's <reading>Oh so</reading> (おそ) terrifying!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you know already!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but it's pretty easy. How do you read all the other "to climb" words? 登る is one example. 上る is another. They're all <reading>のぼ</reading>る, and so is this. Unlike the other climbing words, though, this suggests there's no effort involved. That's why you're "ascending" and not climbing, because climbing is a bit of work.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who can make good use of various <vocabulary>board</vocabulary>s? An avid <reading>eater</reading> (いた)! If you’re an avid eater, you’ll need lots of (cutting) boards to prepare all the delicious food you’re going to eat. This makes boards and eaters the perfect match.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading comes from 極める.
The reading is like 構う, so as long as you know that you know this too.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Just watch out for that rendaku on 戸, which changes the reading to ど. Of course, it will be easy if you already know the word <vocabulary>Edo</vocabulary>!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: One way <vocabulary>to add something to</vocabulary> something else is to just <reading>sew</reading> (そ) it on!

The reading for 添 is what you'd expect. The reading for 付 is the on'yomi reading ふ, which you've learned with 付近. But for this word it becomes ぷ from the rendaku fairies. Just think of an <vocabulary>attachment</vocabulary> where instead of a document or something, you get an attachment of <reading>poo</reading>p (ぷ). What a gross attachment. Your friend who likes to send poop attachments is dumb.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's stuck onto things making it all jukugo and such.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 米 so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The biggest problem when you buy <vocabulary>unpolished rice</vocabulary> is the <reading>mic</reading>e (まい)! Mice like to eat and sleep in unpolished rice, so you have to be careful when you buy a bag that you get rid of all the sleeping mice before you try to cook it.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word, which means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You already know this reading for 請, but not for 申, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Today you finally submitted your <vocabulary>application</vocabulary> for a new <reading>shin</reading> (しん). Your old one had to be painstakingly removed after you banged it against a table. Anyway, congrats on the application for your new shin!
The reading is, strangely, the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. <reading>りゃく</reading>す.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as 痛い. No pain here.
The reading is 痛み and 止める put together into one word. Not too painful, right? Just remember the rendaku on the ど.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi readings. You've learned this reading for 相, but not for 次. Instead of giving you a mnemonic, we think it's easier to remember that 次ぐ being read つぐ comes from the 次 reading つぎ. Not too hard! All in all, that makes this あいつぐ.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is 眠い plus 薬 put together in one ... zz zzzzzZZZzz
Just remember that くすり turns into ぐすり here because of rendaku.
The reading comes from 眠い.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
If something accumulates, you can start with one, but you need at least <reading>two</reading> (つ) things to say it has accumulated. If you don't, then there's nothing accumulating at all.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just think of the first part of the word <reading>in</reading>dex (いん). Where do you search? In the index.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

What can you do if you want something <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to become tight</vocabulary>? You need to hug your <reading>shee</reading>p (し) really close until...

The sheep tightens into a tiny little ball. Cute!
The reading for this is the stem form of both verbs, so 締め (しめ) and 切り (きり), put together!

The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With 織 you can pull the reading from 織る. With 物 you've probably seen it enough to know that it's often もの and not ぶつ. Just think of a piece of <vocabulary>cloth</vocabulary> that is <reading>mono</reading>chrome.

The reading is 腹 plus 減る put together. With these two combined, you have はらがへった.

In casual speech, you might hear 腹減った without the が more often. The version with が is more common in writing or fixed expressions like 腹が減っては戦ができぬ (you can't fight on an empty stomach).
The readings come from 腹 and 切る. If you're lucky, you already know the word harakiri as it's made its way into English as well.

The readings are 腹 plus 立つ put together. The たつ becomes だつ as a standard reading though.

While はらだつ is the standard reading for 腹立つ, it's usually found in more formal settings or writing. You'll probably hear はらたつ more often in everyday conversations, as it’s a shorter, more colloquial way of expressing 腹が立つ!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. One thing to note though:

This word uses the かい reading for 街 (not がい). And even when 街道 is a suffix, it never gets rendaku'd! Remember this by imagining every <vocabulary>main road</vocabulary> being full of <reading>kay</reading>aks (かい) for some reason. Just a traffic jam of kayaks up and down the 街道.

meanings.meaning: To Get To The Bottom Of

reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the words 見る and 極める put together. Get to the bottom of this word and learn it.

allMeanings.meaning: To Get To The Bottom Of

reading_mnemonic: The reading isn't the same as 訪ねる, though, I'm afraid. It's おとず. Remember how this means just visiting a place? Unfortunately, you completely forgot what you were visiting. When you finally remember, it's because you were looking down to think. It's to look at the toes of the giant Buddha statue. "<reading>Oh Toes</reading>!" (おとず), you exclaim.

The reading is the same as 見る, which you have to do when you are examining a patient. So, you look and see all you can about the patient while you examine them, making this reading <reading>み</reading>る as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should have no troubles here.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You <reading>saw so</reading> (さそ) much in this person that you decided <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary> them to dinner.
What's another word for "to accept" or "to receive"? How about 受ける? They share a reading!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This word uses the on'yomi of 豚. You haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You really like <vocabulary>tonkatsu</vocabulary> so you just ate a whole <reading>ton</reading> (とん) of it. Imagine how you feel after eating a ton of <vocabulary>breaded pork cutlet</vocabulary>.
The reading is the same as 貸す.
You learned this reading already when you learned 迷う! Just swap the う for an い.
The reading comes from 迷惑, so if you know that you know this (and then this vocab word won't be unsolicited as well!)
The reading comes from the words 道 and 迷う.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
